Description: Vertical ropes or square-mesh barriers to prevent cetacean entry into trawl mouth.
Inclined grids or escape hatches to deflect large animals like dolphins or seals.
Pingers or AHDs to repel dolphins and porpoises from trawls.
Restrict trawling depth (>250–300m) or time (daylight) to avoid cetacean encounters.
Colored streamers over trawl warps to deter bird strikes and entanglement.
Laser light projected to discourage birds from approaching trawl area.
Rigid or flexible grids allowing elasmobranchs and turtles to escape trawls.
Eliminating chains in front of trawls to reduce skate and shark catch.
Inclined grids with escape openings to allow turtles to exit trawls.
Foldable grids for small trawlers to reduce turtle, shark, and debris catch.
Shorter tow times and slower hauling to reduce turtle drowning risk.
Reverse manoeuvre and small-mesh panels to let dolphins escape safely.
Strengthened nets to resist dolphin depredation in sardine fisheries.
Sound-emitting devices to reduce dolphin encirclement and depredation.
Avoid setting nets around dolphins, whales, or whale sharks.
Fish at night or outside breeding grounds to minimize seabird bycatch.
Water spray or floatline sinking to reduce bird entrapment during hauling.
Escape panels to allow sharks to exit purse seine pockets.
Non-entangling biodegradable FADs to prevent ghost fishing and shark entrapment.
Ban on setting nets around whale sharks or large pelagics.
Use of odour cues to steer sharks away from nets or FADs.
Reduce net slack to lower entanglement probability.
Allow entangled large mammals to break free safely.
Emit sounds to alert cetaceans and avoid entanglement.
Use of chemical cues to discourage approach.
High-visibility mesh panels to alert dolphins or porpoises.
Emit sound to deter diving seabirds.
Light or colour signals to reduce seabird entanglement.
Deploy nets deeper or at night to reduce bird interactions.
Use of magnets or electropositive metals on nets.
Attach green or UV lights to nets to deter turtle entry.
Adjust net depth and soak time to minimize turtle catch.
Modify hook shape and spacing to prevent dolphin interaction.
Haul gear slowly and avoid hauling with cetaceans nearby.
Emit acoustic signals to keep dolphins and whales away.
Visual deterrents to conceal bait or hooks.
Use weighted lines or blue-dyed bait to reduce bird access.
Deploy lines under water or from vessel side to reduce bycatch.
Protect bait until submerged or scare birds visually.
Emit sound or light cues to deter seabirds during setting.
Use of circle hooks, metal baits, or non-squid bait to deter sharks.
Magnetized hooks repel sharks via electromagnetic fields.
Olfactory deterrents like necromone compounds to deter sharks.
Emit noise to repel sharks from baited hooks.
Set hooks deeper and reduce soak-time to lower shark interactions.
Use larger circle hooks and fish instead of squid bait to reduce hooking.
Use LEDs or illuminated lures to deter turtles.
Use acoustic release buoys instead of ropes to prevent entanglement.

MitigationTechnique: Weak links and galvanic time releases
Description: Allow lines to break or corrode over time to prevent whale entanglement.
Reduce shark entry by magnetic field deterrence.
Change trap net geometry or mesh to avoid dolphin entry.
Provide escape routes for turtles trapped inside nets.
Emit acoustic signals to deter marine mammals near traps.
Use flags or panels to increase trap visibility to birds.
